Title.evidence: Background.: Racial disparities in use of surgical therapy for lung cancer exist in the United States.

Participants.evidence: Participants included 113 surgeons (38 practicing surgeons, 75 trainees); of these, 76 were white non-Hispanic (67%), and 37 were other self-identified racial categories.

Intervention.evidence: Trainees and practicing thoracic surgeons read a race-neutral vignette, provided an initial estimate of the percentage risk of major surgical complications, viewed a video randomized to a black or white SP, provided a final estimate of risk, and scored the likelihood that they would recommend operative therapy.

Objective.evidence: We hypothesized that physician race and SP race in videos influence surgeon decision making.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: viewed a video randomized to a black or white SP

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants included 113 surgeons (38 practicing surgeons, 75 trainees)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Percentage changes between initial and final risk estimates were not significantly related to patient race ( p = 0.11) or surgeon race (white versus other; p = 0.52).
